A leading ENT care facility, the Department of ENT (otolaryngologists) at Hope Hospital provides thorough treatment for a range of ENT conditions affecting the ear, nose, throat, and related structures of the head and neck.

These conditions frequently impact many organ systems. In order to determine the best course of treatment for a patient’s head and neck issues, the specialists examine the entire body. The specialists coordinate care across several departments as necessary, including plastic surgery, ophthalmology, dentistry, dermatology, neurology, speech and audiology, oncology, pulmonary medicine, endocrinology, neurosurgery, and others, depending on the situation. 

Why choose Hope Hospitals for ENT?

Our team of ENT doctors at Hope Hospital treats a variety of ENT conditions, from ear and throat infections to more complicated conditions like tumours and hearing loss.

Our ENT surgeons collaborate with experts in ophthalmology, speech Pathology, dermatology,immunology,neurosurgery, allergy, oncology, paediatrics, pulmonary Medicine, and Oncology to improve patients’ quality of life by managing ENT problems.

Ear

Ear infections, ear discharge, hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and a few cranial nerve problems are among the most prevalent ear disorders. At Hope Hospital’s ENT department, some problems relating to congenital disorders of the outer and inner ear are also addressed.

Nose

Allergic rhinitis, a deviated nasal septum, and chronic sinusitis are among the most prevalent nose-related conditions. The treatment of the sinuses and nasal cavities is one of the otorhinolaryngologist’s main specialties. Allergies, polyps, nasal blockage, bleeding, tumors, and odor disorders are a few other issues with the nasal area.

Throat

Speech, singing, swallowing, and feeding difficulties may be among the issues affecting this important region. The otolaryngologists are skilled in treating diseases of the larynx, throat, and esophagus as well as abnormalities of swallowing and voice.

Head & Neck

Otolaryngologists treat benign and malignant tumors, facial injuries, facial palsy, and facial deformities that are associated with the Head and Neck region.

Our services for ENT

Ear

  • Meniere’s disease  
  • Tinnitus
  • Eardrum perforation
  • Ear deformities
  • Deafness or age related hearing loss 

Nose

  • Nasal airway obstruction
  • Nasal polyps
  • Allergic rhinitis
  • Deviated septum
  • Sinusitis
  • Snoring and sleep apnea
  • Nose bleeds

Throat

  • Sore throat
  • Tonsillitis
  • Throat tumors
  • Tonsillectomy
  • Vocal cord and airway disorders
  • Thyroid and parathyroid problems
  • Laryngotracheal airway problem
  • Laryngitis
  • Cleft palates
  • Swollen adenoids
  • Trouble swallowing

Head and Neck

  • Malignant tumors
  • Facial palsy
  • Deformities of face
  • Facial trauma
  • Vertigo

Our treatment for ENT

For Ear

    1. Radical mastoidectomy is a type of mastoidectomy known as a canal wall down mastoidectomy that does not repair the tympanic membrane or the ossicles, externalizing the middle ear and the mastoid.
  • Tympanoplasty is an eardrum repair procedure known as microsurgery, or surgery performed under a microscope or endoscope.
    1. Stapedotomy is a successful surgical procedure that improves patients’ quality of life when used to treat otosclerosis. The combination of skilled hands, minimum surgical trauma, and suitable surgical technique can result in a satisfactory hearing outcome.
    2. Ossiculoplasty is the rebuilding of the middle ear ossicular chain that has been damaged or destroyed using a series of interposed devices that aid in restoring the ossicular chain’s original mechanics for transmitting sound energy to the inner ear.
  • Myringoplasty is a procedure carried out by an otolaryngologist to close an eardrum hole.
  • Pure tone audiometry is the gold standard for identifying the kind, severity, and pattern of hearing loss in patients, as well as the proportion of conductive to sensorineural loss.
  • Ear ventilation tubes are tiny cylinders that are surgically placed into the eardrum. They are typically constructed of plastic or metal. The middle ear is ventilated by an ear tube, which also prevents fluid from building up behind the eardrum.
  • Cochlear implants deliver sound impulses to the hearing (auditory) nerve without using the damaged parts of the ear.

 

For Nose

  • Endoscopic DCR is a method used to cure epiphora, or excessive tearing, which results from a blocked nasolacrimal drainage system. Since the results are equivalent to the external technique, endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy (E-DCR) employing telescopes has gained a lot of traction among otolaryngologists.
  • Turbinoplasty They might facilitate breathing for you. If the turbinates in your nose are excessively big and obstruct the airways in your nose, you might need one of these operations. A drip pad for blood and mucus may be placed under your nose.
    1. Endoscopic orbital decompression Graves’ orbitopathy is treated surgically with endoscopic orbital decompression (thyroid eye disease). It takes off the top and bottom walls of the eye’s orbital bone. Endoscopes and other tiny tools are used by surgeons when operating through the nose.
  • Septoplasty involves cutting the bone and cartilage that divide the area between your two nostrils to make them more straight (septum).
    1. CSF rhinorrhea repair uses a free graft approach or an obliterative technique employing free belly fat to treat a rhinorrhea inside the sphenoid sinus. As an alternative, hydroxyapatite bone cement can be used to fix the sphenoid sinus defect.
  • Nasal surgery is a procedure to alter the appearance of the nose. Because breathing and the shape of the nose are related, a rhinoplasty may occasionally be done to improve both breathing through the nose and the appearance of the nose.
  1. Nasal endoscopy A procedure called a nasal endoscopy is used to examine the sinus and nasal passageways. With the aid of an endoscope. This is a tiny, flexible tube that has a light and a camera on it.

For Throat

  • Foreign body removal The use of forceps, water irrigation, and suction catheters are examples of removal techniques.
    1. Vocal polyp is a laryngoscope that is put into the patient’s mouth while they are unconscious, and a microscope is used to enlarge the view of the vocal folds. The polyp is removed with specialized tools. After surgery, a patient receives brief voice rest before starting vocal therapy with a speech therapist.
  • Tumor surgeries Surgery can frequently successfully and safely remove a tumor with few side effects if it is small and circumscribed.
  • Adenotonsillectomy is a procedure that removes the tonsils and adenoids.
  • Tonsillectomy is the surgical removal of the two oval-shaped tissue pads called tonsils, one on each side of the throat.

For Head and Neck 

  1. Head and neck cancer surgeries Otolaryngology, a subspecialty of which head and neck surgery is a part, specializes in the surgical treatment of conditions affecting the head and neck.

Skull base surgeries are done by removing anomalies on the underside of the brain, the base of the skull, or the top few vertebrae of the spinal column, as well as non-malignant and cancerous growths.

 

What could make your nose bleed?
  • Weather changes
  • Excessive intake of alcohol
  • Self induced nose picking
  • Infection
  • Hypertension
  • Use of blood thinning medication

 

What can induce a strange sensation of taste or smell?

Head trauma, viral upper respiratory infections, and nasal or sinus conditions are the three most frequent causes of taste problems. Head traumas and upper respiratory tract infections are the most frequent causes of taste abnormalities. Occlusions in the nasal and oral airways, hormone imbalances, drug side effects, etc. are a few uncommon causes.

 

Is surgery necessary for sinusitis?

Only when the problem has become chronic and has not improved will surgery be necessary. The ENT specialist may advise sinus surgery if you have chronic sinusitis. Therefore, unless the condition is serious, sinus surgery is not always required.

 

How can a voice that is getting weaker be treated?

As their vocal chords deteriorate with age, many people notice changes in their voice. There may be vocal fatigue, voice breaks, pitch changes, and hoarseness. It may become more difficult to be heard and require more effort to talk. The otolaryngologist may administer an injection to “bulk up” the voice cords as an uncomplicated form of treatment.

 

What are the typical symptoms of swallowing issues?

Food being caught in the throat, having trouble swallowing medicines, and coughing while eating are all warning signs that something is wrong. It’s crucial to have a medical checkup because swallowing difficulties might be harmful. The formation of pouch-like sacs in the back of the throat or a muscular tightening around the esophagus can both cause difficulties like these. With minimally invasive surgery, both problems can be cured.

 

What is the procedure for cochlear implants?

It is an electronic device that is surgically implanted and used by those who gain little or not at all from traditional hearing aids. It replaces the non-functioning components of the ear and is frequently referred to as a “bionic ear.” It has the ability to transform sound into an electrical signal that activates the eighth nerve.

Children and adults with substantial hearing loss can experience sound more clearly thanks to cochlear implants. The auditory nerve is stimulated directly by the implants, bypassing the inner ear’s destroyed hair cells, which allows information to be sent to the nerve. They are not in charge of repairing or developing new hearing.
